<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">some protest, some desire to affirm something, behind the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">slashed cloaks; the stiff ruffs; the wrought chains</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the loops of pearls. The cost was great; the discomfort</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">appaling; yet the fashion prevailed. Was it perhaps,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The Elizabethans are silent. There is no little

              <corr>rhythm</corr>

            <choice>

              <corr>speech</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unfamiliar. It is only expressive of certain emotions.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Thus when Lady <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-abac" key="Bacon, Anne">Ann Bacon</rs> writes to <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-fbac" key="Bacon, Francis">her son</rs> she is a preacher</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">addressing a subordinate. Fear of God and distrust of man</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">surround her as with the walls of a dungeon. She admonishes;</l>
